response.answer_text: Since the question is about Hungarians, and not Hungarian language, I think we should focus on the ethnicity of people living in Hungary. Otherwise the language is Finno-Ugrian (Ugric branch), from the Uralic language group, not related to Indo-European Slavs. Surprisingly Hungarians show only traces of genes that are common in other Uralic speakers. Genetically Hungarians very much alike neighboring countries: Slovakians, Austrians, Romanians, Southern slavs. Seeing this I think there is not much difference between Hungarians and slavs. This may be because after Conquest of Hungary (895–896) the Hungarian rulers slowly changed the local population to Hungarians, which population was the same as the origin for other Slavic people (even they may have been mostly Slavs).  Previously, Avars were ruling in the territory of Hungary (a Turkic speaking group), also Gepids and Goths (both Germanic), Moravians (Slavic), Bulgarians (Turkic), Huns, Romans, Pannons, Celts, etc. They all have left their traces in the local population. Even the Hungarian Empire had “immigrants”: Cumans (kun), Pechenegs (besenyő), Slovaks, Germans, Vlachs were settled in greater number, and also among the nobles Italians, French, Austrians, etc have been Hungarised. Very similar processes have worked for the neighbouring Slavic population, too. I think that - genetically - you can hardly distinguish a Hungarian from a neighboring Slav. Also, among the family names, the top 10 includes Tóth (means Slovak or Slavic), Horváth (means Croatian), and there are a lot of Némeths (German), too. This also suggests that Hungarian population is very mixed.

Ethnically and linguistically, no, they are not even remotely Slavic - they are a unique group of people with distant ties to other Ugric tribes of the Ural mountains, like the Khanty and Mansi. They are not even Indo-European, with their closest relatives in Europe being the very distantly-related Finns and Estonians.   (Traditional Khanty and Mansi families) Genetically, however, most Hungarians are closely related to Slavs and to Romanians (especially Slovenians and Moldovans) - they share over 50% of the exact same ancestral markers, and the three groups often closely resemble one another.   (A Ukrainian group celebrating Polish-Hungarian Friendship Day in Krakow) This is because the ancestral Hungarians, the Magyars, didn’t arrive to Europe until around 850 AD. Prior to the Magyar tribes migrating en masse to today’s Hungary, the area was previously inhabited by Slavic tribes in the west and by groups related to modern Romanians in Transylvania. Much like how the vast majority of people in Britain still have mostly Celtic ancestry despite their language and culture coming from Germanic or French roots, Hungarian people are mostly descended from ancestors that predate the Magyar’s arrival in Europe.

Wow! That’s a question from when I was a teenager. No, I have nothing to do with Hungary, my elders are from Bessarabia, but there was a book. Rather а short novel inside. It narrated the story of a poor Jewish boy from some Hungarian hole who, thanks to his extraordinary willpower, managed to overcome his disability and poverty learned a lot of languages by himself and fulfilled his cherished dream. And the dream was to find those ancient Magyar, about which he was told by his older friend, a janitor, or the shoemaker who lived next door. When the boy grew up and mastered the oriental languages, he dressed as Darwīsh and went on a long adventure journey through Central Asia full of danger and risk. It was very nice and entertaining and made a great impression on me. Once, after many years since I've read the book — I was already living then in Haifa — I retold this story to my co-workers as an exemplary work of a Russian writer a favorite of the Soviets that did not hesitate to write a positive fiction about a Jewish kid notwithstanding what Russophobes are telling about alleged Russian anti-Semitism. One of them asked me, what was the name of the story. Vámbéry, I replied. Then, without saying a word, he went to his desk and produced from the drawer a monography by a prominent scholar in Turkic languages, a member of many academies, the Royal Society among them. My jaw dropped when I found out that the novel I'm so fond of is not a fine fiction but the real man's story. A story of courage, strong will, and everlasting quest after knowledge. As a layman, I will refrain from addressing the title question, but it seems that the acquaintance with works of Ármin Vámbéry is a must for everyone interested in the history of Hungarian people. Hungarians are Finno-Ugric in the same sense in which Poles are Slavic. The Finno-Ugric (in other languages, the order is reversed: we call them Ugrofinns in Czech) family of languages is exotic and most other European families don’t understand a word, not even “television”, of course. (Ugro- refers to the old name for Hungary.) It’s because the Hungarians, Estonians, and Finns ultimately came from much more distant East than the Slavs and others. At some point, their ancestors lived in the Ural, basically in Asia, and “Uralic” is the name for the broader family of languages that includes the Finno-Ugric ones and a few other, less important or extinct ones. Theories exist in which Finno-Ugric languages are also close to Mongolian. Those aren’t believed to be true much today but they have been plausible enough to be believed by many experts for a long time. “Central Asia” may still look as an OK description of the “old homeland” of the Finno-Ugric people.

Hungarians or Magyars are an ethnic group primarily associated with Hungary. The word Hungarian has also a wider meaning, because – especially in the past – it referred to all inhabitants of the Kingdom of Hungary irrespective of their ethnicity. Specifically, the Latin term natio hungarica referred to all nobles of the Kingdom of Hungary regardless of their ethnicity. There are around 9.5 million Magyars in Hungary (2001). Magyars have been the main inhabitants of the Kingdom of Hungary that existed through most of the second millennium. Following its disappearance with the Treaty of Trianon, Magyars have become minority inhabitants of Romania (official: 1,440,000; see: Hungarian minority in Romania), Slovakia (520,500), Serbia (293,000; largely in Vojvodina), Ukraine and Russia (170,000), Austria (40,583), Croatia (16,500), the Czech Republic (14,600) and Slovenia (10,000). Significant groups of people with Magyar ancestry live in various other parts of the world (e.g., 1,400,000 in the United States), but unlike the Magyars living within the former Kingdom of Hungary, only a minority of these preserves the Hungarian language and tradition.

They are ethnically (for whatever that’s worth) related to tribes of West Siberia. Their language is a member of the Uralic family, meaning, that unlike almost all other languages in Europe, it is not Indo-European. The ancestors of modern Hungarians (again allowing for inevitable ethnic intermixing, etc) invaded the Carpathian basin in the 9th Century, settled, and eventually, under King Saint Steven (Istvan) I, became Christians, about two centuries later.

No, Hungarians are NOT Slavic. Their tribe was the Magyars. A historian aptly observed, “Hungary is an island of Magyars surrounded by a sea of Slavs.” The Hungarian language bears ZERO resemblance to any Slavic tongue.
